channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkish Police Say U.S. Embassy Was Target of Bomb Plot
item.description: Twelve are arrested in an alleged Al-Qaeda-linked plot to attack the embassy in Ankara, a synagogue in Istanbul and other targets.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh Police Arrest Acting Editor of Pro-Opposition Paper
item.description: The editor, Mahmudur Rahman, was charged with sedition at a time when strikes by opposition forces have frozen travel and are crippling the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: The Lede: Canadian Teen’s Suicide Ignites Calls for Review of Rape Case
item.description: The recent suicide of a Canadian teenager has revived outrage that the authorities did not do enough to investigate allegations that she was gang-raped in 2011 and bullied after photographs of the assault were shared and posted online.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: ArtsBeat: Jay-Z Responds in Song to Critics of Cuba Trip
item.description: The rapper released a new track, “Open Letter,” responding to criticisms of his trip to Cuba with Beyoncé.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES C. MCKINLEY JR.

item.title: Timeline of Escalating Tensions
Russia Skips Hybrids in Push for Natural Gas Cars
item.description: Russia, the world’s second-largest producer of natural gas, is making a bet that methane-powered cars are an alluring market for future growth.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buses powered by natural gas refueling at a station on the outskirts of Moscow. Natural gas costs about $2 a gallon less than gasoline in Russia.

item.title: The Lede: Filmmakers Capture Chaos After Airstrikes in Syria
item.description: Video of air strikes by the Syrian government released this week by Human Rights Watch and PBS Frontline offer harrowing glimpses of the impact of such bombings.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Israeli Court Rules for Women at Western Wall
item.description: A magistrates’ court ruled that five women who had been detained for wearing prayer shawls and singing aloud were not disturbing public order.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Hundreds Detained in Immigration Raid in Russia
item.description: Many of those arrested during a raid on a market in St. Petersburg were migrants from Central Asia and the mainly Muslim North Caucasus.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: India Ink: Investigation of 1984 Sikh Massacre Continues in India
item.description: At least three more witnesses to be questioned.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: One of the buildings set on fire in the Daryaganj neighborhood of New Delhi on Nov. 2, 1984, during the riots that followed Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's assassination.

item.title: Way of the World: Obama’s Biggest Battle May Be Unwinnable
item.description: In many ways, Barack Obama is the ideal figure to confront the issue of income equality in the United States. Unfortunately for him, the problem continues to metastasize.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: Franco Biondi Santi, Winemaker, Dies at 91
item.description: The popularity of Mr. Biondi Santi’s Tuscan red wine, which was invented by his grandfather in Italy, skyrocketed in the last half-century.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC ASIMOV

item.title: India Ink: Image of the day: April 11
item.description: Gudi Padwa festival celebrations in Mumbai, Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A child dressed as Lord Shiva participating in a procession in Mumbai to celebrate Gudi Padwa, which marks the new year in the state of Maharashtra.

item.title: ‘Django Unchained’ Is Pulled From China’s Theaters
item.description: The Oscar-winning movie was abruptly pulled on its opening day despite reports that the filmmakers had edited scenes to comply with the wishes of Chinese censors.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: A woman looked at a poster for the film "Django Unchained" on Thursday outside a theater in Beijing.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: France Debates the Merits of the Bra
item.description: A French scientist suggests women might be better off without their bras. His findings have prompted a debate about the pros and cons, tempered with some notes of Gallic humor.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Employees of the French lingerie maker Lejaby in 2012 with a patriotic example of their handiwork.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Thatcher as Theater: A Prime Minister Playwrights Couldn’t Resist
item.description: Five seminal British plays that would never have come about without Margaret Thatcher.
item.dc:creator: By MATT WOLF
item.media:description: Haydn Gwyne plays Margaret Thatcher and Helen Mirren is Queen Elizabeth II in "The Audience" by Peter Morgan on stage in London.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Story of Women’s Labor Camp Abuse Unnerves Even China
item.description: A woman’s diary, and a hard-hitting magazine story, cast a spotlight on the conditions at re-education-through-labor camps in China, which government officials have said they will reform.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from a Sina microblog account, showing torture of female inmates in China, according to a person who posted it.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 11
item.description: Women’s increasing role in Syria’s conflict; questions about the overhaul of Indonesia’s military; new Auschwitz prosecutions; oil in Kurdistan; and a dramatic end to Malaga’s Champions League appearance.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A poultry market in Wuhan closed live poultry trading on Saturday.

item.title: Zao Wou-Ki, Seen as Modern Art Master, Dies at 92
item.description: Zao Wou-ki, who moved to France from China in 1948, was one of the few Chinese-born painters to be considered a master of 20th-century modern art in the West.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: Zao Wou-ki moved to France in 1948 and later became a French citizen. His works were influenced by both European abstraction and traditional Chinese brushwork.

item.title: South Korea Moves to Defuse Tensions With the North
item.description: South Korea softened its tone on Thursday amid concerns that North Korean missile tests are imminent, and its president moved to calm foreign investors.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: The Lede: Taboo on Speaking Ill of the Dead Widely Ignored Online After Thatcher’s Death
item.description: Even in ancient Sparta, apparently, people had to be advised to resist the urge to speak ill of the dead.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Irish nationalists celebrated the death of Margaret Thatcher on Monday in Ulster with flags and graffiti.

item.title: India Ink: In Assam, Searching for New Crops and Farming Methods for Depleted Soil
item.description: Deforestation, increased flooding and climate change make the soil sandier, but some crops thrive.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN ORLAND
item.media:description: Farmers working in their paddy fields in Jorhat district of Assam on March 29.

item.title: Syrian Government Accused of War Crimes
item.description: A report by Human Rights Watch said the Syrian Air Force carried out indiscriminate and in some cases deliberate airstrikes against civilians.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Captains Charged Fatal in Hong Kong Boat Collision
item.description: Hong Kong police on Thursday filed manslaughter charges against the captains of two boats that collided in October in the city’s deadliest maritime disaster in more than four decades.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: India Ink: Kaziranga Remains a Success Story, Despite Rising Poaching
item.description: Northeastern India’s national park could serve as a conservation model for others.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A one-horned rhinoceros inside the Kaziranga National Park in Assam.
